pull.title: Improve code readability. Exhaustive changes for each class of cleanup.
pull.body:
Improve code readability:
* Use `auto*` instead of `auto` for pointers
* ~~Avoid shadowing variable~~
* Separate assignment from function call
* ~~Remove redundant code~~

These changes are all exhaustive.

events.message: readability: Use auto* instead of auto for pointers

rename.to: Improve code readability. Exhaustive changes for each cleanup.

rename.from: Improve code readability. Exhaustive changes for each cleanup.
rename.to: Improve code readability. Exhaustive changes for each class of cleanup.

events.body: Tend to NACK. All of these are subjective style cleanups. Unless they have a major impact on developer experience or user experience, they are probably not worth to "fix".

events.message: readability: Separate assignment from function call

events.body: Closing I misread a report: these fixes are not exhaustive. Sorry.

comments.body: We don't do these changes, since it is non-trivial to prove the refactoring does the right thing:  #10136

Wasn't the problem that people used ancient compilers? That this only remaining case is correct should be obvious to us humans, no? :-)

This was one of the comments:

> And there is still value in compiling with Wshadow periodically (with a carefully chosen compiler) and seeing if it finds any bug.

I'm using a carefully chosen compiler :-)

> this only remaining case

This clearly isn't the only remaining case.

See for example rest.cpp

```cpp
auto process_utxos = [&vOutPoints, &outs, &hits](const CCoinsView& view, const CTxMemPool& mempool) {
```
where one of the args shadows the global mempool
This change makes it harder to switch to smart pointers later, no?
Oh, I misread a report. Sorry. Reverted the shadowing change :-)
